newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: Price rise impact low on NZ's WH - analysts.
newsitem.headline: Price rise impact low on NZ's WH - analysts.

text.p: Analysts on Tuesday said publisher Wilson and Horton could expect up to a $2 million increase in revenues from a weekend hike in the cover price of its flagship newspaper the New Zealand Herald.
An analyst who declined to be named told Reuters he saw an increase of little more than NZ$2 million in revenues.
"At the best I would say no more than $2 million. Obviously it has a beneficial effect, but the increase would have been budgeted this year in any case," he said.
A Wellington-based analyst, who also asked not to be named, said the impact would not be great and could be less than $1 million if the paper's current circulation was maintained.
On Saturday the Auckland-based Herald announced it would lift the cover price of its five weekday papers from 70 cents to 90 cents but would maintain the Saturday price at $1 a copy.
New and existing subscribers would be offered discounts to partially offset the price rise, it added.
Herald general manager Phillip Crawley declined to discuss expected revenue increases, but said they would not be large.
"I wouldn't get too excited about the difference, to be honest. It is not that significant in the greater scheme of things," Crawley told Reuters.
He said the Herald, which sells 50 percent of its newspapers on subscription and 50 percent as casual sales, had a range of expectations and was not certain how the promotion would affect revenues.
SBC Warburg analyst Paul Richardson said he expected a significant rise in earnings before interest and tax from the cover price hike.

He said the muted reaction of Wilson and Horton's share price, up five cents to $11.70 on Tuesday, reflected the lack of liquidity in the stock and also that expectations of higher prices had already being factored in.
The Wellington-based media analyst said the Herald could expect to lose some circulation as a result of the price rise.
"The previous two times the Herald increased its cover price there was a loss of circulation," he said. "That also affects your ability to charge advertisers more."
Announcing the price rise, the Herald told its readers the increase followed major improvements to the product, including a 25 percent increase in editorial content in a year.
"The costs associated with these changes and rises in other operating charges necessitate the price rise," the paper said.
Wilson and Horton is 85 percent owned by Tony O'Reilly's Independent Newspapers Ltd.
The Herald's circulation had been in the doldrums in recent years despite strong population growth in its main Auckland market.
But in the six months to March the Herald lifted its circulation by 2,696 to 229,398 over the same year-ago period.
